Award.AwardTitle: Arithmetic and Zariski-dense subgroups in algebraic groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project addresses several important problems in the investigation of arithmetic and general Zariski-dense subgroups of semisimple algebraic groups. One of the central themes in the project is the analysis of weakly commensurable Zariski-dense subgroups. The notion of weak commensurability was introduced earlier in a joint work of the PI and G. Prasad, and its analysis for arithmetic groups has led to a resolution of several problems in differential geometry dealing with length-commensurable and isospectral arithmetically defined locally symmetric spaces. In the current project, some finiteness results which were previously known only for arithmetic groups are expected to be generalized to arbitrary Zariski-dense subgroups. This work is likely to have interesting consequences for non-arithmetically defined locally symmetric spaces. It is also related to the problem in the theory of algebraic groups of to what extent an absolutely almost simple algebraic group over a field K is determined by the isomorphism classes of its maximal K-tori. This part of the project will build on the PI's recent results analyzing division algebras having the same maximal subfields. The PI also intends to continue the investigation of the congruence subgroup problem.

Generally speaking, the project focuses on the analysis of a very broad class of matrix groups (Zariski-dense subgroups of semisimple algebraic groups) based on the information about the eigenvalues of their elements. This approach is fundamental in the representation theory of finite groups, but as was discovered by the PI and G. Prasad it can also be used to characterize many arithmetic groups (which are special groups whose elements are matrices with integer matrices). The goal of the project is to extend some of these results to groups much more general than arithmetic. This work has applications to the famous question ''Can one hear the shape of a drum?'' in the context of some special spaces called locally symmetric spaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several years ago, G.Prasad and the PI introduced new techniques for the investigation of arithmetic and general Zariski-dense subgroups of algebraic groups. These techniques were based on the notion of weak commensurability. The analysis of weakly commensurable arithmetic subgroups carried out by Prasad and the PI enabled them to resolve several long-standing problems in differential geometry about length-commensurable and isospectral locally symmetric spaces (informally speaking, they have been able to answer the famous question ``Can one hear the shape of a drum?" for many locally symmetric spaces).  The fact that the methods developed for this purpose were so general has led to several natural conjectures basically stating that at least qualitatively some key results that were originally established for arithmetic groups should remain valid for arbitrary Zariski-dense subgroups.  In particular, it should be possible to reconstruct the ambient absolutely almost simple algebraic group as an algebraic group over its field of definition (up to finitely many possibilities) from information about the eigenvalues of elements of an arbitrary Zariski-dense subgroup - this is one aspect of the new phenomenon termed ``eigenvalue rigidity." These conjectures were systematically addressed in the project. The research involves, and has applications to, many adjacent areas including division algebras and the Brauer group, Galois cohomology of algebraic groups, local-global principles, some aspects of arithmetic geometry. In particular, one of the obtained results states that given a central division algebra over a finitely generated field, of degree prime to the characteristic of the field, there can exist only finitely many division algebras over this field having the same maximal subfields as the given algebra. Furthermore, a general approach has been developed to extend this finiteness theorem to absolutely almost simple groups of all types.  Other results obtained include a useful criterion for centrality of the congruence kernel in the congruence subgroup problem for S-arithmetic subgroups of absolutely almost simple algebraic groups over global fields and a method for constructing valuations on division algebras. 

The results of the research described in the project were published in 11 papers and were reported on at various venues including the International Congress of Mathematicians in Seoul (2014).
